timeline.bodyText: Why 16 has been chosen as the initialization value?
timeline.author: RaulGracia

replies.bodyText:
This class is very similar to Java's ArrayDeque. That class also chooses 16 as a default init value.
For our purposes (BlockingDrainingQueue) this initial value makes little difference. We only create the queue once and then hang on to it. So it will eventually grow to a "steady-state" length and then reuse the same element array.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText:
This code is assuming that this: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.html#setRemoveOnCancelPolicy-boolean-
is set to true on the thread pool. confirm is the case and maybe document this.
timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText:
Yes, I am aware of that. All of our executors have that flag set (see ExecutorServiceHelpers.java) precisely for this reason.
FYI, this code is borrowed from Futures.futureWithTimeout. I didn't want to reuse that method since I wanted the leanest possible implementation which was tied into the take() future above.

timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText:
poll(100) returns one of those SimpleDeque.WrapQueue instances, to which we cannot add anything. Previously, it returned an ArrayDeque to which we could add new items, so the test code was lazily reusing that one.
Since the WrapQueue is closed to additions, I have to make a copy of it. Copying is done using its iterator, so all its elements are contained in the same order. There is no need to test the functionality of WrapQueue - that is already done in the SimpleDequeTests class.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText:
These two operations are not thread safe but this class extends BlockingDrainingQueue which calls itself threadsafe.
There are multiple race conditions:

There could be two threads the first perform the check and then both call addInternal even though the second one is before the first violating the invariant above.
There could be two threads which insert in one order but set lastSequenceNumber in the other order resulting in the wrong sequence number.
timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText: Look at the javadoc for lastSequenceNumber. This method can only be invoked from its superclass which holds a lock while doing so. As such, no further synchronization is needed.
